dc:description: KCNJ2 was evaluated for autosomal dominant catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (CPVT). Variants in KCNJ2 are associated with Andersen-Tawil syndrome (ATS), a condition associated with dysmorphic features, periodic paralysis and prominent U waves on ECG. It has been classified as a definitive gene for ATS by the LQTS Gene Curation Expert Panel. As the ECG abnormalities in patients with KCNJ2 variants can be interpreted as prolonged QT intervals, it was also curated for isolated LQTS and found to have limited evidence. KCNJ2 variants have also been implicated in CPVT (referred to as CPVT3 in early reports). However, as in the case with isolated LQTS, it is unclear if these reports actually represent atypical presentations of ATS without extra-cardiac features. A number of reports describe patients with KCNJ2 variants presenting with CPVT-like arrhythmogenic symptoms and without any extra-cardiac features (Tester et al, 2006, PMID:16818210; Kimura et al, 2012, PMID:22589293; Kalscheur et al, 2014, PMID:24561538), supported by functional studies demonstrating effects of the variants on IK1 current in cellular assays (Vega et al, 2009, PMID:19843922; Kimura et al, 2012, PMID:22589293; Kalscheur et al, 2014, PMID:24561538). As a consequence, KCNJ2 scored with limited evidence for involvement in CPVT based on these reports. However, none of these patients presented unequivocally with a classical CPVT phenotype and demonstrated features such as subtle ECG U wave abnormalities and bidirectional VT at rest which may be suggestive of atypical and cardiac-specific ATS rather than a true CPVT diagnosis. The expert panel therefore agreed to classify KCNJ2 as Disputed for CPVT. As patients with pathogenic KCNJ2 variants may present with a phenotype that can resemble typical features of CPVT, it may be beneficial to include this gene in extended arrhythmia genetic testing panels for patients with a CPVT-like phenotype if no causative variants are found when sequencing validated CPVT genes. However, any detected variants should be interpreted in the context of the known genotype-phenotype relationships for KCNJ2, in particular by investigating for subtle phenotypic features associated with ATS. Note: All CPVT genes were curated by 3 separate blinded teams. The evidence and scores reached by these 3 teams was reviewed by the CPVT Gene Curation Expert Panel (GCEP). The classification and summary presented here is the conclusion of this GCEP's analysis according to evidence teams' efforts. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Catecholaminergic Polymorphic Ventricular Tachycardia Gene Curation Expert Panel on 20th January, 2021 (SOP Version 7).
curationReasonDescription: None of the reported patients presented unequivocally with a classical CPVT phenotype and demonstrated features such as subtle ECG U wave abnormalities and bidirectional VT at rest which may be suggestive of atypical and cardiac-specific ATS rather than a true CPVT diagnosis. The expert panel therefore agreed to classify KCNJ2 as Disputed for CPVT.

evidence.dc:description: Functional evidence demonstrated for two different variants detected in patients with CPVT-like phenotype.

No measurable current is recorded in CHO cells transfected with G144D and T305S variant. Co-expression of WT and G144D or T305S yelded a reduced inward and outward I Kir2.1 compared with WT alone, respectively 89% and 96% for G144D and 49% and 89% for T305S (figure 4).
evidence.rdfs:label: G144D and T305S variants in CHO cells

evidence.dc:description: No measurable current is recorded in CHO cells transfected with R67Q variant. KCNJ2 WT-R67Q co-expression in Cos-1 cells showed rectification index similar to WT under basal conditions. PKA-simulated cathecolaminergis stimulation failed to increase peak outward current density (sensitivity to calcium) (figures 2-4).
evidence.rdfs:label: R67Q variant in CHO cells

evidence.dc:description: KCNJ2 WT-V227F co-expression in Cos-1 cells yelded Ik1 indistinguishable from WT under basal conditions. But PKA-simulated cathecolaminergic stimulation caused a marked reduction of outward Ik1.
evidence.rdfs:label: V227F variant in COS-1 cells

evidence.dc:description: The presence of prominent U waves on ECG may suggest a phenotype of cardiac-specific ATS.

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Sanger sequencing of RYR2, CASQ2, KCNJ2.

evidence.dc:description: Subtle U wave abnormalities on resting ECG may suggest a diagnosis of ATS rather than CPVT.

evidence.rdfs:label: Case no. 5
evidence.detectionMethod: PCR, DHPLC and sanger sequencing of RYR2, CASQ2, KCNQ1, KCNH2, SCN5A, KCNE1, KCNE2, ANK2, KCNJ2

evidence.dc:description: Subtle U wave abnormalities on resting ECG may suggest a diagnosis of ATS rather than CPVT.

evidence.dc:description: The presence of PVCs at rest, prolonged QUc and prominent U waves suggests this patient had cardiac-specific ATS rather than CPVT.
